brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to investigate the changes in subcutaneous adipocyte size,
      number and gene expression after weight loss and to assess whether those changes contribute
      to decreases in ectopic fat accumulation and insulin resistance in women between ages of
      16-32.

clinical_study.brief_title: Study to Investigate Benefits of Weight Loss in Young Adults and Adolescents

detailed_description.textblock:
There are no studies in young women that have prospectively studied changes in fat cell
      size, gene expression and insulin sensitivity during the transition from overweight/obese to
      normal weight. Our preliminary data suggest that the presence of ectopic fat accumulation
      and insulin resistance in obese children could be considered an "early phase" in the
      development of T2DM. We hypothesize that a 10% weight loss will restore/improve insulin
      sensitivity. Furthermore, we speculate that the decrease in subcutaneous fat mass after
      weight loss is due to a decrease in mean adipocyte cell size, but not cell number.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Women ages 16-32

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  They will not be on any medications that are known to alter glucose or insulin
             metabolism, such as oral steroids, or certain psychiatric medications, such as
             Xeleca, Lithium and Paxil. Patients on diuretics will be excluded.

intervention.description: Patients will meet weekly with a registered dietician.

clinical_study.official_title: Study to Investigate Benefits of Weight Loss in Yound Adults and Adolescents

primary_outcome.description: To assess in young women, the effects of weight loss on abdominal fat distribution.
primary_outcome.measure: Abdominal fat re-distribution with weight loss

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: With 10% weight loss, assess changes in cell size distribution and gene expression of adipocytes from the subcutaneous adipose depot.
secondary_outcome.measure: Adipocyte cell size distrubtion and gene expression

collaborator.agency: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD)

clinical_study.study_design: Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Health Services Research
